H0.text: who came up with the first working periodic table. John Newlands

H1.text: who came up with the first working periodic table. Julius Lothar Meyer

H2.text: who came up with the first working periodic table. Antoine Lavoisier

H3.text: who came up with the first working periodic table. Dmitri Mendeleev

A4.text: Lothar Meyer published a paper in 1864 describing 28 elements classified by their valence, but with no predictions of new elements.

A5.text: Mendeleev published his periodic table of all known elements and predicted several new elements to complete the table in a Russian-language journal.

A6.text: Meyer acknowledged Mendeleev's priority in developing the periodic table.

A7.text: Mendeleev published his periodic table in 1869, and Meyer's revised version followed a few months later.

A8.text: Periodic table according to Lothar Meyer (1870)

A9.text: The first periodic table to become generally accepted was that of the Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev in 1869; he formulated the periodic law as a dependence of chemical properties on atomic mass.
